title: Hiatal hernia after esophagectomy – a report of two cases
patient: A 34-year-old woman was admitted with squamous cell cancer of the cervical esophagus. She underwent total hybrid McKeown resection of the esophagus (VATS with laparotomy and cervicotomy) with pharyngogastric anastomosis as well as microjejunostomy, pyloromyoplasty, the Kocher maneuver, and three-field lymphadenectomy. Stage IA (pT1aN0Mo) was confirmed by postoperative specimen examination. Tachycardia (100/min) was observed between the 4th and 7th postoperative day. Oral contrast X-ray examination revealed stenosis of the pylorus at the level of the hiatus (). The pylorus was compressed by the malpositioned colon. A decision was made to perform a reoperation, which included colon repositioning, hiatal plasty, and right hemicolectomy due to ischemia and necrosis. The postoperative period was complicated by peritonitis, which was successfully treated with peritoneal lavage.
